Canada has arrested Huawei’s chief financial officer following a US extradition request, reigniting tensions between Washington and Beijing just days after Donald Trump and Xi Jinping tried to resolve their trade conflict at the G20 summit.

Canadian officials on Wednesday said they had detained Meng Wanzhou, the daughter of Ren Zhengfei, founder and chief executive of the Chinese telecoms group, on Saturday in Vancouver. Ms Meng, who became one of Huawei’s four deputy chairpersons this year, will face a bail hearing on Friday.

Quick line from Cowen .....

VV75 no but the Cod War is coming
BE11:16am

The Commerce and Treasury Departments are proceeding with a revamp of export control and investment rules that could introduce material new restrictions on Chinese firms, particularly in high tech and new technologies where the U.S. wants to discourage Chinese leadership (e.g., 5G). We expect the Chinese will want guarantees that their firms will not be singled out, and new rulings against firms like Huawei and ZTE could complicate the broader negotiations. The arrest of the Huawei CFO (and daughter of the founder) in Canada last night at the behest of the U.S. for extradition to the U.S. over alleged Iran sanctions violations is just one example over the past two months since the Pence speech that shows that the trade and tariff issues may be the easier issues to tackle.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

Tariffs get all the attention, but do not forget the other two levers in the 301 investigation: export controls and investment restrictions. This summer, the Congress passed expansive legislation in both of these areas: the Export Control Reform Act (ECRA) and Foreign Investment Risk Review Modernization Act (FIRRMA , i.e. CFIUS 2.0). Per the ECRA, the Commerce Department last month began public comment (ends December 19) on “whether there are certain emerging technologies that are essential to the national security of the US”. The list of products that could be affected include basically all things tech/AI: genomics, computer vision and audio manipulation technology, microprocessor technology, quantum computing, mind-machine interfaces and flight control algorithms. This supports the narrative that export controls along with new FIRMMA rules on Direct Foreign Investment could be the lasting and significant legacy of Trump protectionism, e.g. could be hard to reverse even if there are "great" deals that resolve tariffs.

BE11:17am

Bottom Line: Markets can at least digest tariffs and model their impacts for companies and markets. Non-tariff trade barriers, export controls and investment restrictions represent a possible exogenous shock to global trade flows that are incredibly challenging to predict with second and third level impacts. With a pinch of hyperbole, this has the potential to create dozens of ZTE-type situations as global supply chains seize overnight.

FATDAZ @blank canvas business or pleasure

(@Lawro: yes, apologies, but it was the only photo on my roll that didn't show anyone's faces. Responsibility overrode aesthetics.)

What is being omitted here?@thatginamiller puts this and five other awkward questions to the @AttorneyGeneral below 👇 https://twitter.com/endthechaosuk/status/1070607529363865600/photo/1

We believe this is a clear signal that the trade war is escalating to a new
level. We think the probability of US and China reaching a trade deal by Mar 1 has dropped to 30% from 40%. US business interests in China face higher risk than before.
Huawei has been widely recognized as one of the most successful technology companies in China. This news pushed policy makers in Beijing into an awkward position. Public opinion in China will likely become more negative in respect to the trade war, and potentially against US companies. The government may find it difficult to tell the public that they have offered significant concessions to the US. The trade talk has just been resumed at the G20 meeting; now its outlook has darkened.

BE11:20am

[T]echnology has become the focus of bilateral economic tension. The US government already proposed imposition of export controls on "emerging technologies". This Huawei event suggests indeed technology has become the new battleground.

BE11:26am

We would now ascribe 10% to a Hard Brexit, 50% the ‘current deal’ (or one that looks very similar) and 40% Remain / EEA. Of course, such numbers are necessarily qualitative in their assessment – what matters is not the number, but the direction of travel. The narrative is moving away from Hard Brexit.

However, markets do not seem to have fully priced that in yet or indeed, at all. Whilst we have adjusted our view, the market is still in a state of scenario planning paralysis. When it comes to Brexit, the tail risk discussion dominates conversations, to such an extent it seems the market gives a near equal weighting to diverse scenarios; hence the continued hedging demand in GBP (two charts showing that we are reaching extremes of that below).

BE11:29am

Q: How sensitive are UK equities to the various possible scenarios?
In a deal outcome (our base case), our FX strategists’ estimates imply
nEUR/GBP at 0.85 - a rise of 5% for GBP. This is a slight positive for UK domestic stocks, but scope for large outperformance is limited. UK growth is likely to remain weak and politics would move on to negotiations on the final shape of Brexit, where again there is no consensus. FTSE 100 may suffer as GBP rises, but the recent correlation with Sterling has risen to close to zero.
In a no-deal outcome, the market is likely to discount a substantial hit to GDP.
nWe estimate that each 1pp off UK GDP shaves 3pp off FTSE 100 EPS growth, 5pp off FTSE 250 and 11pp off GSSTUKDE. Assuming a substantial de-rating, it would not be hard to envisage domestic stocks down 30% or more. A fall in GBP would provide some cushion to FTSE 100, but not entirely. That said, ‘no deal’ is also the least preferred option of Parliament and thus we think most likely avoided. Even in the event the upcoming vote rejects the Withdrawal deal, we think it is unlikely that the market would jump to discounting the full extent of a ‘no deal’ Brexit in GBP or domestic-exposed equities.
Another referendum, extend or revoke Article 50? We would expect a
nnear-term rally in UK domestic stocks, at least reversing the recent sell-off. But given that it would lead to an entirely new range of uncertainties, we doubt the room for upside is substantial.

rw42 Meh, i just think there's just better routes to gather data than something on the device. With stuff like packet captures you could monitor all data that leaves your phone - if you go to HK or mainland china it would be far easier for them to tap the lines at the phone exchange without you knowing.
Excel Developer @IslandDweller: progress is made, slowly. India this year for example.
BornCynic @RW42 - you do not realise how the security services work. They get some dirt on you and then you have to do what they say. The US giving LSD to people and then introducing prostitutes into the mix sort of sums it up.......

And Liberum's Joe Brent is 24 hours too late with his "buy the Brexit risk" note.

BE11:38am

Housebuilders’ shares are down 26% in 2018. They have
de-rated from 2.0x to 1.3x book value as the risk of a
disorderly Brexit has risen. The shares now show extreme
value and we can see at least 20% upside (29% TSR) if a
smooth Brexit materialises. We also calculate that plausible
downside in a disorderly exit is now discounted in share
prices. A Corbyn-led government is an undiscounted risk,
and this would most likely be negative for housing demand.

BE11:39am

"A Corbyn-led government .... would most likely be negative for housing demand" is an interestingly intricate bit of secondary effect prediction ......

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Back to the top, though.

BE11:40am

We see at least 20% upside (29%
TSR) for the sector in a smooth Brexit
transition because valuations are now
very depressed and this would
significantly de-risk the outlook.
Although the market is likely to be
dull, it should be good enough for
builders to continue volume growth
where able, and maintain margins by
taking advantage of lower land prices
and re-engineering houses. Valuation
looks overly pessimistic. The sector
yield (9.1%) is twice that of the UK
market. Dividend sustainability is
very under-appreciated.

Excel Developer #Housing pre-fabs coming off an assembly line in a factory require less labour.
BE11:40am

A disorderly, “no deal” Brexit could
cause an economic shock and a
recession. We believe a prudent
scenario could see house prices fall
10% and volumes 20%. Allowing
housebuilders scope for some
mitigating action, we find that
earnings would fall around 40% from
our central estimate in this scenario.
This would mean the sector trading
not at 7x P/E, but 14x. Historical
cycles have seen multiples of over
13x trough earnings, so this could
mean that significant plausible
downside risk is already discounted.

unconvincing

higher rates as the impact of raised government borrowing pushed yields up. These negatives would offset the positive specific policies for housebuilding. 1H EBITA came in slightly below GSe which is negative. However, the miss was driven by the plastics division which is split out as a discontinuing operation now following the strategic review. Margins progressed positively in-line largely with our expectations but should be somewhat a relief compared with investor concerns. Organic volume growth came in at 3.2%, somewhat down from the strong growth of 5.2%. While the growth level remains healthy, the significant slowdown could be taken negatively.

DS Smith’s share price has fallen by over 30% over the past two
months. This has been driven entirely by multiple contraction with
no change to earnings forecasts. While corrugated demand has
slowed over the period, this is in-line with our expectations and
also our full year assumption. Corrugated prices have increased
and OCC costs look stubbornly low. In this environment, there is
no cause to change our forecasts. The recent sell-off therefore
looks overdone.
